title: 115_s3036
content:
The "Keep Families Together Act" limits the separation of families. The "Keep Families Together Act" prohibits the removal of a child from their parent or legal guardian near the border unless authorized by a State court or child welfare agency. The Chief Patrol Agent or Area Port Director can authorize the separation of a child from their parent or legal guardian if the child is in danger of abuse, trafficking, or is a danger to themselves or others. The Secretary must ensure that any child separation is documented in writing with the reason and evidence provided. SEC. 3. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SEPARATION BY AGENTS OR OFFICERS. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, must develop training and guidance for agents and officers within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The guidance should focus on the best interests of the child, childhood trauma, attachment, and child development to standardize the implementation of section 2(a)(3). The Secretary of Health and Human Services must review the guidance annually to ensure it aligns with current evidence and best practices in child welfare, child development, and childhood trauma. The guidance must also incorporate the presumptions described in section 4 and be evidence-based. The guidance and training developed under this section must be evidence-based. All agents and officers of designated agencies must complete training on adherence to the guidance upon hire and annually. Chief Patrol Agents and Area Port Directors must also complete training on adherence to the guidance and 90 minutes of evidence-based child welfare practice training annually. SEC. 4. PRESUMPTIONS.

The presumptions include a strong favor towards family unity, keeping sibling groups together, and a general presumption against detention for families and children.

SEC. 5. REQUIRED POLICY FOR LOCATING SEPARATED CHILDREN. SEC. 5. REQUIRED POLICY FOR LOCATING SEPARATED CHILDREN.

The Secretary must publish final guidance within 180 days on how parents can find children separated under section 2(a). Written notification and language access in English and Spanish will be provided. SEC. 6. REQUIRED INFORMATION FOR SEPARATED FAMILIES. The Secretary must provide monthly updates to parents or legal guardians of separated children, including status reports, education and health information, changes in immigration status, and other details to promote family reunification. The Secretary must submit a report annually on instances of child-parent separation, detailing the relationship, age, gender, length of separation, criminal charges, asylum claims, prosecution outcomes, reasons for separation, and supporting evidence. The Secretary must report annually on child-parent separations, including reasons, evidence, sibling contact, unaccompanied status, and discretionary information. SEC. 8 clarifies that if a child is separated from a parent, parental rights are presumed to remain intact unless terminated by a court. SEC. 9 states that this Act does not override Federal or State child welfare laws. SEC. 10 requires a GAO report on the prosecution of asylum seekers. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the prosecution of asylum seekers from 2008 to 2018, including the number referred for prosecution, criminal charges filed, and convictions secured. The Comptroller General will report on the number of asylum seekers separated from their children, resources spent on prosecuting asylum seekers, those who went through immigration proceedings, and those deported before proceedings. The report will be submitted to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like "agent" and "officer" which encompass contractors of the Federal Government. The term "child" refers to individuals under 18 with no permanent immigration status. "Committees of jurisdiction" are specified as the Senate's Committee on the Judiciary and the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, along with the House of Representatives' Committee on the Judiciary. The definition of "danger of abuse or neglect at the hands of the parent or legal guardian" excludes migrating to or crossing the United States border. The curr_chunk defines terms like "designated agency" as the Department of Homeland Security, Department of Justice, and Department of Health and Human Services. It also explains that a "finding" is an individualized assessment by a trained agent or officer, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security.
